findings.title: Skill does not specify a license
findings.description: Skill manifest does not include a 'license' field. Specifying a license helps users understand usage terms.
findings.remediation: Add 'license' field to SKILL.md frontmatter (e.g., MIT, Apache-2.0)

findings.title: CREDENTIAL HARVESTING detected by YARA
findings.description: Detects potential exposure of sensitive information like API keys, passwords, tokens, and certificates: export TRANSCRIPT_API_KEY
findings.remediation: Review and remove credential harvesting pattern

findings.title: Hardcoded API Key Requirement with External Service Dependency
findings.description: The skill requires users to obtain and store a TRANSCRIPT_API_KEY from an external third-party service (transcriptapi.com). While the skill itself doesn't contain hardcoded secrets, it creates a dependency on an external commercial API service that requires user registration and credential management. The instructions guide users to store the API key in shell configuration files (~/.zshenv), which could be exposed if the user's environment is compromised. Additionally, all API calls transmit this credential to an external service, creating a potential data exposure vector if the external service is compromised or malicious.
findings.snippet:
TRANSCRIPT_API_KEY required. Get one free (100 credits, no card):
- [transcriptapi.com/signup](https://transcriptapi.com/signup) → Dashboard → API Keys
- Store: `echo 'export TRANSCRIPT_API_KEY="sk_..."' >> ~/.zshenv && source ~/.zshenv`
findings.remediation: 1. Clearly document the third-party dependency and data sharing implications in the skill description. 2. Warn users that their API key will be transmitted to transcriptapi.com with every request. 3. Consider implementing key validation or rotation mechanisms. 4. Advise users on secure credential storage practices beyond shell config files (e.g., using credential managers). 5. Add transparency about what data is sent to the external service.

metadata.overall_assessment: The youtube-channels skill presents MEDIUM security risk primarily due to external API dependency and incomplete transparency. The skill requires users to register with and transmit credentials to a third-party commercial service (transcriptapi.com), creating potential data exposure vectors. While the skill itself contains no malicious code (no script files present, only curl examples in documentation), it lacks critical manifest metadata (license, compatibility, allowed-tools) that would help users assess security implications. The skill facilitates transmission of user queries to an external service without explicit privacy warnings. No prompt injection, command injection, or data exfiltration attempts were detected in the instruction body. The skill appears to function as documented - providing YouTube channel information via an external API - but needs improved transparency about third-party dependencies, data sharing, and credential management.

findings.title: Incomplete Manifest Metadata - Missing Critical Fields
findings.description: The skill manifest is missing several important optional fields that help users assess security and compatibility: 'license' (not specified), 'compatibility' (not specified), and 'allowed-tools' (not specified). While these fields are optional per the agent skills specification, their absence makes it difficult for users to understand the skill's intended operating environment, licensing terms, and tool usage restrictions. The skill makes external API calls but doesn't declare this in compatibility information. The absence of 'allowed-tools' means there are no declared restrictions on what agent tools this skill might use.
findings.snippet:
YAML Manifest Details:
- license: Not specified
- compatibility: Not specified
- allowed-tools: Not specified
findings.remediation: 1. Add 'license' field to clarify usage terms (e.g., 'license: MIT'). 2. Add 'compatibility' field noting external API dependency and network requirements (e.g., 'compatibility: Requires internet access and TRANSCRIPT_API_KEY environment variable'). 3. Add 'allowed-tools' field to explicitly declare which agent tools are needed (e.g., 'allowed-tools: [Bash]' since the examples show curl commands). 4. This improves transparency and helps users make informed decisions about skill usage.

metadata.overall_assessment: The youtube-channels skill presents MEDIUM security risk primarily due to external API dependency and incomplete transparency. The skill requires users to register with and transmit credentials to a third-party commercial service (transcriptapi.com), creating potential data exposure vectors. While the skill itself contains no malicious code (no script files present, only curl examples in documentation), it lacks critical manifest metadata (license, compatibility, allowed-tools) that would help users assess security implications. The skill facilitates transmission of user queries to an external service without explicit privacy warnings. No prompt injection, command injection, or data exfiltration attempts were detected in the instruction body. The skill appears to function as documented - providing YouTube channel information via an external API - but needs improved transparency about third-party dependencies, data sharing, and credential management.

findings.title: External API Data Transmission Without Explicit User Consent Flow
findings.description: The skill facilitates transmission of user queries (YouTube channel handles, URLs, IDs) to an external third-party API (transcriptapi.com) without implementing an explicit user consent or confirmation mechanism. While the skill's description mentions working with YouTube channels, it doesn't explicitly warn users that their search queries and channel interests will be transmitted to a third-party service. This creates a minor privacy concern as user behavior and interests are shared with an external entity.
findings.snippet:
All API endpoints send user input to transcriptapi.com:
curl -s "https://transcriptapi.com/api/v2/youtube/channel/resolve?input=@mkbhd"
curl -s "https://transcriptapi.com/api/v2/youtube/channel/latest?channel_id=UC_CHANNEL_ID"
curl -s "https://transcriptapi.com/api/v2/youtube/channel/videos?channel_id=UC_CHANNEL_ID"
findings.remediation: 1. Add a privacy notice in the skill description explaining that queries are sent to transcriptapi.com. 2. Include information about transcriptapi.com's data handling practices or link to their privacy policy. 3. Consider adding a confirmation step for first-time use. 4. Document what data is transmitted (channel IDs, handles, continuation tokens) and what is received (video metadata, statistics).

metadata.overall_assessment: The youtube-channels skill presents MEDIUM security risk primarily due to external API dependency and incomplete transparency. The skill requires users to register with and transmit credentials to a third-party commercial service (transcriptapi.com), creating potential data exposure vectors. While the skill itself contains no malicious code (no script files present, only curl examples in documentation), it lacks critical manifest metadata (license, compatibility, allowed-tools) that would help users assess security implications. The skill facilitates transmission of user queries to an external service without explicit privacy warnings. No prompt injection, command injection, or data exfiltration attempts were detected in the instruction body. The skill appears to function as documented - providing YouTube channel information via an external API - but needs improved transparency about third-party dependencies, data sharing, and credential management.
